source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Euphorbiaceae

items.item_name: Euphorbia characias (see note following genus description)
Euphorbia hirta (see note following genus description)

leads.lead_text: Stems erect; leaves usually alternate on lower stems, subopposite or opposite above, bases symmetric; stipules minute or absent; seed usually with a caruncle; involucral glands entire or horned
Stems prostrate, decumbent or ascending; leaves opposite, bases asymmetric; stipules present, interpetiolar; seed lacking a caruncle; involucral glands usually with petaloid appendages
Robust shrubs to c. 2 m high; branches stout; leaves usually absent from much of lower stems, leaf scars prominent

Small shrubs or herbs usually less than 50 cm high with slender to thickish, semi-succulent branches; leaves usually present throughout or absent only from largest basal stems, leaf scars not usually prominent
Plant tomentose, rarely glabrescent; glands variable, often horned; capsule villous
Plant virtually glabrous; glands suborbicular, irregularly lobed, not horned; capsule glabrous
Shrubs or subshrubs; cyathia solitary; native species from north-western Victoria only
Erect herbs, rarely shrubby; cyathia in compound inflorescences or solitary; naturalized species
Leaves linear to narrow-lanceolate; stipules apparently absent; involucre to 1 mm long; styles entire, capitate
Leaves lanceolate or oblanceolate to spathulate; stipules present; involucre 1–2 mm long; styles cleft to the middle into 2 filiform recurved stigmas
Upper stems distinctly finely pubescent; seeds smooth
Upper stems glabrous or, if ever hairy, then seeds tuberculate
Leaves opposite or subopposite and decussate, mostly longer than 40 mm long
Leaves all or mostly alternate (if opposite, not distinctly decussate), mostly less than 40 mm long (but to 80 mm in E. davidii)
Glands of involucre entire, more or less elliptic or oblong
Glands of involucre with crescentic or horn-shaped appendages
Leaves more or less oblong, sessile throughout; capsule tuberculate
Leaves ovate to obovate, at least the cauline ones petiolate; capsule smooth
Leaves obovate (broadest in upper half), evenly finely serrate; petiole <1 mm long
Leaves more or ovate (broadest in lower half), unevenly and irregularly toothed; petiole >5 mm long
Annuals, to c. 30 cm high; seeds tuberculate, grooved and/or pitted
Perennial (sometimes short-lived); seeds smooth
Seeds tuberculate; stem leaves linear to oblong
Seeds laterally grooved, at least on one face; stem leaves ovate to obovate or (rarely) oblong
Seeds with 3–5 lateral grooves on ventral and dorsal surfaces; plants usually single-stemmed, but much-branched apically; uncommon weed, currently known only from the Wimmera in western Victoria
Seeds with longitudinal groove ventrally, pitted dorsally; plants often branched near base; common weed of gardens etc., mostly from moist or watered sites
Paired bracts of inflorescence obtuse; capsules wrinkled along keels; caruncle of seed minute, reniform, c. 0.5 mm diam.
Paired bracts of inflorescence acuminate to apiculate; capsules smooth; caruncle of seed prominent, peltate, boat-shaped, c. 2 mm long.
Cyathia in axillary or terminal cymes; leaves 10–40 mm long
Cyathia solitary in leaf axils; leaves 2–15 mm long
Plant at least partially hairy
Plant glabrous

Stems rooting at nodes and/or brownish root buds present on undersurface of the nodes; leaves 1–1.2 times longer than wide; leaf margins entire; involucral gland appendages conspicuous, 0.1–0.2 mm long, 0.3–0.6 mm wide; capsules 1.2–1.4 mm long, 1.3–1.7 mm diam.; seeds 0.7–1.2 mm long, 0.4–0.7 mm diam; an uncommon weed of disturbed sites, including footpaths, urban botanic gardens, and garden beds

Stems not rooting at nodes; leaves 1–2 times longer than wide; leaf margins entire or minutely toothed (sometimes distally or apically only); involucral gland appendages conspicuous to inconspicuous, 0.05–0.3 mm long,  <0.1–0.6 mm wide; capsules 1.5–2.2 mm long, 1.5–2.4 mm diam; seeds 1.1–1.5 mm long, 0.6–1 mm diam.
Stipules on at least one side of stem united between petioles, triangular to broadly triangular with entire to toothed (but not laciniate) margins; widespread
Stipules separate or only shortly united between petioles (then appearing deeply bipartite), the margin deeply lobed or laciniate, the whole structure often appearing digitate; far north-west only
